Posted By: Cheza (8/9/2010 12:10:57 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Vanilla is my favourite flavour of icecream, so its not suprising that vanilla creatures are some of my favourite cards. They get such a bad cop from people, so I guess I have limited to thank for making them useful, because their simplicity is appealing to me. As for P/T, look at it this way: a vanilla 4/2 for 4 CMC in green is a pretty bad card (they can get a 4/3 with regenerate for the same CMC), however green doesn't have removal. White can get a 2/3 flyer with first strike, and it has sideboard removal against black, but that isn't the same thing. Aggressive black creatures are good in limited because you have removal to help clear any obstructions. Removal and burn are some of the most highly sought-after abilities in Magic, so its not surprising that these two colours would get lower toughness on average in order to be balanced overall.
posts.html:

White can get a 2/3 flyer with first strike, and it has sideboard removal against black, but that isn't the same thing. Aggressive black creatures are good in limited because you have removal to help clear any obstructions. Removal and burn are some of the most highly sought-after abilities in Magic, so its not surprising that these two colours would get lower toughness on average in order to be balanced overall.

Posted By: Blackworm_Bloodworm (7/10/2010 5:49:26 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Though I wish Vanillas more often competed with non-vanilla (such as [Leatherback Baloth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leatherback Baloth)) I do think they help evoke the flavor of different colors the best. There's only so much damage or toughness you can put on a non-vanilla before it gets absurd, but you can always subtract and make a mediocre common that gets the message across.   
  
I wish better cards more often represented the toughness/power ratios of the colors better. Red and Green seem to be the only ones that are consistent (because green \*should\* be equal on both ends and Red is almost always top heavy.)
posts.html:
Though I wish Vanillas more often competed with non-vanilla (such as Leatherback Baloth) I do think they help evoke the flavor of different colors the best. There's only so much damage or toughness you can put on a non-vanilla before it gets absurd, but you can always subtract and make a mediocre common that gets the message across.

I wish better cards more often represented the toughness/power ratios of the colors better. Red and Green seem to be the only ones that are consistent (because green *should* be equal on both ends and Red is almost always top heavy.)
